name: TheAtlantic
text: "Apparently powerless to stop the chaos, Trump has now decided to embrace it, hoping that if he was unable to deliver the security he promised, perhaps heightened fear would motivate voters nearly as well," writes @GrahamDavidA: https://t.co/uueRW7r8Tb

name: TheAtlantic
text: The risk of catching COVID-19 is much lower outdoors. So why aren't more schools considering holding classes outside? @olgakhazan reports: https://t.co/0E5X4mdzMi

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Atlantic Daily: 'The U.S. Is Simply Not Ready for Big Films to Return', by @mimbsy https://t.co/3yVas9KBAs

name: TheAtlantic
text: “As much as he loved oil and canvas, his true resonance is with the screen. To this day, millions of people gaze at the videos he made and feel a deep emotional connection to them.” @MooneyMichaelJ explores Bob Ross’s enduring popularity: https://t.co/wG4auZ9wBz

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Flitcraft parable is a warning to white people: If you're not careful, you will find peace again. You will find comfort in a world designed with you in mind. The novelist Richard Russo writes about a parable for this historical moment: https://t.co/6ZXB9k0I6q

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Even if Congress somehow decreed the breakup of all four tech giants, the U.S. would still have an astounding number of industries controlled by a tiny number of firms," @ddayen writes: https://t.co/4RYppwrxVe

name: TheAtlantic
text: Donald Trump promised religious voters that he would protect them with his Supreme Court appointments. The justices are not necessarily playing along. @emmaogreen reports: https://t.co/QGJEBFUo4Z

name: TheAtlantic
text: Children who have experienced abuse or dysfunction often have difficulty learning—but an Oklahoma teacher named Heather Boyle knows how to work with them. @laura11D reports: https://t.co/XXMplMDLDQ
